answers: No, it is never impossible to get credit so long as there are no price controls or quotas. In most of the United States, the impetus for housing is so strong that it's one sector of credit that has nearly no price regulation, price in this case being interest rates. Also, Fannie & Freddie, who ultimately finance most mortgages in the US now require banks to buy back loans if they fail, so banks are only financing the most creditworthy. All is not lost because markets are like rivers if not fully dammed: they find a way through. In your case, you can get a fully-financed mortgage if you're willing to pay interest rates probably double what you could otherwise get in the market with good credit. If the foreclosure process is quick and benefits the lender more in your state, the interest rate will be even lower. Your creditors will most likely be individuals you find at mortgage investment clubs and religious institutions.  If you shop around, you'll be surprised at how low a rate you might get. Also, since the cost of your prospective home is so low, it's very easy for an investor flush with cash and few investments to take a flier on a mother committed to her children who only needs $50,000. The FHA has been vastly expanded, and since your individual credit is clean, there may be a chance to get financing through it, but be prepared for red tape.

prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

Can I buy a new house before selling my current house?[/INST]
pred:
Yes, it is possible to buy a new house before selling your current house, but it may not be the best financial decision for everyone. Here are some pros and cons to consider:

Pros:

1. Flexibility: By buying a new house before selling your current house, you have more flexibility in terms of the timing of the sales process. You may be able to sell your current house at a time that is convenient for you, rather than feeling rushed to sell it quickly.
2. Avoid Double Mortgage Payments: If you sell your current house before buying a new one, you may be able to avoid making double mortgage payments. This can help you save money on your mortgage payments and reduce your overall financial burden.
3. Less Stress: Buying a new house before selling your current house can reduce the stress of managing two homes simultaneously. You may be able to focus on moving and getting settled in your new home without worrying about the sale of your current house.

Cons:

1. Possible Loss of Equity: If you sell your current house before buying a new one, you may not have enough equity to put towards the down payment on your new home. This can make it more difficult to qualify for a mortgage on the new house, or you may have to pay more upfront costs.
answers: I sold my house and had been in the market looking for a replacement house for over 6 months after I sold it. I found someone willing to give me a short term, 3 month lease, with a month to month after that, at an equitable rate, as renters were scarcer than buyers.By the time I found a house, there were bidding wars as surplus had declined (can be caused seasonally), and it was quite difficult to get my new house. However, appraisers help this to a degree because whatever the seller wants, is not necessarily what they get, even if you offer it. I offered $10k over asking just to get picked out of the large group bidding on the house. Once the appraisal came in at $10k below my offer, I was able to buy the house at what I expected. Of course I had to be prepared if it came in higher, but I did my homework and knew pretty much what the house was worth. The mortgage is the same as the lease I had, the house is only 10 years' old and has a 1 year warranty on large items that could go wrong. In the 3 months I've been in the house, I have gained nearly $8k in equity....and will have a tax writeoff of about $19,000 off an income off a salary of $72,000, giving me taxable income of $53,000... making by tax liability go down about $4600. If I am claiming 0 dependents I will get back about $5,000 this year versus breaking even.

3. Age of accounts: The age of your accounts is a factor in determining your credit score. When you replace a lost card, the new card may not have as long of an age as the old card, which can neg
answers: The true answer is it depends because  it is up to the credit card issuer to follow the right path when issuing a replacement credit card. http://www.bankrate.com/finance/credit-cards/will-replacement-card-hurt-my-score.aspx Typically, issuers will transfer the account history to the new trade line, says Barry Paperno, the consumer operations manager at FICO, the creator of the FICO scoring formula. The new account should have the old open date, so you should retain your payment history, he says. The credit limit and balance should also stay the same. http://blog.credit.com/2014/02/lost-or-stolen-credit-card-hurt-your-credit-scores-76724/ How Issuers Report Replacement Cards We asked the major card issuers how they report replacement cards to credit reporting agencies: American Express: The new card has the same open date and “Member Since” year as the previous card. The balance on the old account number is transferred to the new account number. All payment history transfers over. Bank of America: All transactions and account history are transferred to the new account number when there is a card replacement or renewal. Capital One: The new account number with all the original account data (original open date, etc.) is reported along with a notification to the bureaus that the new account number is replacing the old.  The two tradelines can then be ‘merged’ into one, so that all the applicable payment history, balance, etc. is now under the new account number. Chase: The original tradeline does not change. The history on the account remains, just the account number field is updated with the new account number. There is no “new” tradeline in this scenario.

Can I transfer money from a personal pension to a SIPP, while leaving the original pension open?[/INST]

Yes, you can transfer money from a personal pension to a Self-Invested Personal Pension (SIPP) while leaving the original pension open. This is a common strategy for individuals who want to consolidate their retirement savings into a SIPP but still want to retain the benefits of their original pension.

When transferring money from a personal pension to a SIPP, it's important to understand the tax implications. Generally, any transfer value received from a personal pension is tax-free, but there may be tax implications if you are also transferring funds from other sources, such as an employer's pension scheme or a lump sum from a severance payment. It's essential to seek professional financial advice to ensure that you understand the tax implications and to minimize any potential tax liabilities.

Additionally, you should be aware of any restrictions or penalties that may apply to early pension withdrawals. Personal pensions often have restrictions on early withdrawals, and these restrictions may vary depending on the provider and the type of pension you have. It's important to review the terms and conditions of your personal pension to understand any restrictions that may apply.

Leaving the original pension open can be beneficial if you are not yet ready to retire or if you want to continue to contribute to the pension. You can continue to make contributions

* Low credit

prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

Do dividend quotes for U.S. stocks include witheld taxes?[/INST]
pred:
Thank you for asking! Dividend quotes for U.S. stocks typically do not include withheld taxes. When you buy a stock, the company will typically pay out dividends to its shareholders as a way of distributing some of its profits. The amount of the dividend payment is typically listed as a dollar amount per share, and this amount is what is known as the "declared dividend."

However, the actual amount of money that you will receive as a shareholder is lower than the declared dividend amount due to withholding taxes. The U.S. government requires companies to withhold taxes on dividends paid to non-U.S. investors, known as "withholding taxes." The rate of withholding taxes varies depending on the type of investment and the investor's country of residence.

For example, the current withholding tax rate for foreign investors on dividends received from U.S. stocks is 30%. This means that if a foreign investor receives a dividend payment of $100, they will only receive $70 after the withholding tax is applied ($100 x 30% = $30). The remaining $30 will be remitted directly to the U.S. government on behalf of the investor.

So, when you see
answers: The dividend quoted on a site like the one you linked to on Yahoo shows what 1 investor owning 1 share received from the company. It is not adjusted at all for taxes. (Actually some dividend quotes are adjusted but not for taxes... see below.)  It is not adjusted because most dividends are taxed as ordinary income. This means different rates for different people, and so for simplicity's sake the quotes just show what an investor would be paid.  You're responsible for calculating and paying your own taxes.  From the IRS website: Ordinary Dividends Ordinary (taxable) dividends are the most common type of distribution from a corporation or a mutual fund. They are paid out of earnings and profits and are ordinary income to you. This means they are not capital gains. You can assume that any dividend you receive on common or preferred stock is an ordinary dividend unless the paying corporation or mutual fund tells you otherwise. Ordinary dividends will be shown in box 1a of the Form 1099-DIV you receive. Now my disclaimer... what you see on a normal stock quote for dividend in Yahoo or Google Finance is adjusted. (Like here for GE.) Many corporations actually pay out quarterly dividends. So the number shown for a dividend will be the most recent quarterly dividend [times] 4 quarters. To find out what you would receive as an actual payment, you would need to divide GE's current $0.76 dividend by 4 quarters... $0.19. So you would receive that amount for each share of stock you owned in GE.

prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

Is it possible to block previously authorized ACH access?[/INST]
pred:
Yes, it is possible to block previously authorized ACH access. The National Automated Clearing House Association (NACHA) Rule 4C requires financial institutions to provide mechanisms for customers to request and confirm the termination of ACH access, including previously authorized ACH access.

To block previously authorized ACH access, the customer must provide written instructions to their financial institution requesting the termination of the ACH access. The financial institution must then confirm in writing that the ACH access has been terminated. The customer may also be required to provide a reason for terminating the access.

Once the financial institution receives the termination request, they must notify the ACH operator (such as the Federal Reserve or a private ACH processor) of the termination. The ACH operator will then stop processing ACH transactions in accordance with the customer's request.

It's important to note that once ACH access has been terminated, future ACH transactions will not be processed, but any existing ACH transactions that are in the process of being settled will still be processed and completed.

It's also worth noting that some financial institutions may have additional requirements or procedures for terminating ACH access, so it's always best to consult with your financial institution directly for more information.
answers: I had a similar situation a while ago, and here's what I learned: What are our options here to ensure that this company can't retry to take our money again via ACH? Close existing account and create a new one that has different account number? Yes. As a temporary solution keep ~$0 balance in the account so that their request for $840 can't be fulfilled? However, would our bank incur any fees because of insufficient funds each time the other company tries to charge us again? Bad idea. You may incur penalties for returned payment, or the bank may honor the payment and charge you overdraft fees. Provide to our bank the service termination notice that proves that we   are not in business with the other company anymore and effectively   block them. However, termination notice has only our signature Bank doesn't care. ACH withdrawal is akin to a check. The assumption is that the other side has entitlement. You can put stop payment once its processed and try to reverse it claiming fraud, but the end result will be #1: you'll end up getting a new account set up, while they try to recover the money. This is one of the reasons I'm reluctant allowing standing ACH authorizations any more. Generally, the American banking system is very much geared against the consumers, and in many ways is very retarded. In a more advanced countries (which is almost any other country than the US), the standing withdrawal authorization goes through your bank and can be revoked.

Does the low CAD positively or negatively impact Canadian Investors?[/INST]
pred:
A low Canadian dollar (CAD) can have both positive and negative impacts on Canadian investors, depending on their individual circumstances and investment strategies.

Positive impacts for Canadian investors:

1. Export-oriented businesses: A low CAD can make Canadian exports more competitive in foreign markets, leading to higher sales and profits for companies such as those in the energy, agriculture, and manufacturing sectors.
2. Travel and tourism: A low CAD can make travel to and within Canada more affordable for foreign tourists, leading to increased tourism revenues and economic growth.
3. Real estate: A low CAD can make Canadian real estate more attractive to foreign investors, leading to increased property values and higher demand for real estate.

Negative impacts for Canadian investors:

1. Import costs: A low CAD can increase the cost of importing goods and materials, which can negatively impact businesses that rely on imported goods and materials.
2. Consumer prices: A low CAD can lead to higher consumer prices for goods and services imported from the United States and other countries, which can negatively impact consumers.
3. Central bank policy: A low CAD can make it more difficult for the Bank of Canada to implement monetary policy, as a low currency can lead to higher inflation and potentially reduce the
answers: When you want to invest in an asset denominated by a foreign currency, your investment is going to have some currency risk to it. You need to worry not just about what happens to your own currency, but also the foreign currency. Lets say you want to invest $10000 in US Stocks as a Canadian. Today that will cost you $13252, since USDCAD just hit 1.3252. You now have two ways you can make money. One is if USDCAD goes up, two is if the stocks go up. The former may not be obvious, but remember, you are holding US denominated assets currently, with the intention of one day converting those assets back into CAD. Essentially, you are long USDCAD (long USD short CAD). Since you are short CAD, if CAD goes up it hurts you It may seem odd to think about this as a currency trade, but it opens up a possibility. If you want a foreign investment to be currency neutral, you just make the opposite currency trade, in addition to your original investment. So in this case, you would buy $10,000 in US stocks, and then short USDCAD (ie long CAD, short USD $10,000). This is kind of savvy and may not be something you would do. But its worth mentioning. And there are also some currency hedged ETFs out there that do this for you http://www.ishares.com/us/strategies/hedge-currency-impact However most are hedged relative to USD, and are meant to hedge the target countries currency, not your own.

What is the point of the stock market? What is it for, and why might someone want to trade or invest?[/INST]
pred:
The stock market, also known as the equity market, is a platform where companies can raise capital by issuing stocks, and investors can buy and sell shares of those stocks. prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

Using stop-loss as risk management: Is it safe?[/INST]
pred:
Stop-loss orders are a commonly used risk management tool in financial markets, allowing traders to limit their potential losses on a trade. By setting a stop-loss order at a specific price level, a trader can limit their loss to the amount below that price level if the trade moves against them. However, the question remains whether using stop-loss orders is safe.

The safety of stop-loss orders depends on various factors, including market conditions, the trader's risk tolerance, and the type of stop-loss order used. Here are some points to consider:

1. Market volatility: In highly volatile markets, stop-loss orders may not always work as intended. If prices move rapidly and unexpectedly, there is a higher chance that the stop-loss order may be triggered at a worse-than-expected price, resulting in larger losses than anticipated.
2. Price fluctuations: The price at which a stop-loss order is triggered can vary significantly from the expected price. For example, if a trader sets a stop-loss order at $50, the price may fall to $40 before reaching $50, resulting in a larger loss than expected.
3. Leverage: Using leverage, or borrowed capital, to enter a trade can increase potential losses if the trade moves against the trader. In this case, the stop-loss order may not be enough
answers: A stop-loss order becomes a market order when a trade has occurred at or below the trigger price you set when creating the order. This means that you could possibly end up selling some or all of your position at a price lower than your trigger price. For relatively illiquid securities your order may be split into transactions with several buyers at different prices and you could see a significant drop in price between the first part of the order and the last few shares. To mitigate this, brokers also offer a stop-limit order, where you set not only a trigger price, but also a minimum price that you are will to accept for your shares. This reduces the risk of selling at rock bottom prices, especially if you are selling a very large position. However, in the case of a flash crash where other sellers are driving the price below your limit, that part of your order may never execute and you could end up being stuck with a whole lot of shares that are worth less than both your stop loss trigger and limit price. For securities that are liquid and not very volatile, either option is a pretty safe way to cut your losses. For securities that are illiquid and/or very volatile a stop-limit order will prevent you from cashing out at bottom dollar and giving away a bargain to lurkers hanging out at the bottom of the market, but you may end up stuck with shares you don't want for longer than originally planned. It's up to you to decide which kind of risk you prefer.

Can another tax loss be used to offset capital gains taxes? How does it work?[/INST]
pred:
Yes, another tax loss can be used to offset capital gains taxes. This is known as a "wash sale" rule, and it allows investors to use the loss from the sale of one investment to offset the gains from the sale of another investment within 30 days before or after the sale.

Here's how it works:

Suppose you sold a stock for a loss of $1,000 and then within 30 days, you buy the same stock again. The IRS will consider this a "wash sale," and the loss will be disallowed. However, you can use the loss to offset capital gains from the sale of another investment.

For example, let's say you sold another stock for a gain of $500. You could use the $1,000 loss from the wash sale to offset the $500 gain, reducing your capital gains tax liability to $0.

It's important to note that the wash sale rule only applies to stocks, mutual funds, and exchange-traded funds (ETFs). Other types of investments, such as real estate or bonds, are not subject to the wash sale rule.

Additionally, if you buy the same or substantially identical investment within 30 days before or after the wash sale, the loss will
answers: Capital losses do mirror capital gains within their holding periods. An asset or investment this is certainly held for a year into the day or less, and sold at a loss, will create a short-term capital loss. A sale of any asset held for over a year to your day, and sold at a loss, will create a loss that is long-term. When capital gains and losses are reported from the tax return, the taxpayer must first categorize all gains and losses between long and short term, and then aggregate the sum total amounts for every single regarding the four categories. Then the gains that are long-term losses are netted against each other, therefore the same is done for short-term gains and losses. Then your net gain that is long-term loss is netted against the net short-term gain or loss. This final net number is then reported on Form 1040. Example Frank has the following gains and losses from his stock trading for the year: Short-term gains - $6,000 Long-term gains - $4,000 Short-term losses - $2,000 Long-term losses - $5,000 Net short-term gain/loss - $4,000 ST gain ($6,000 ST gain - $2,000 ST loss) Net long-term gain/loss - $1,000 LT loss ($4,000 LT gain - $5,000 LT loss) Final net gain/loss - $3,000 short-term gain ($4,000 ST gain - $1,000 LT loss)   Again, Frank can only deduct $3,000 of final net short- or long-term losses against other types of income for that year and must carry forward any remaining balance.

Is a debt collector allowed to make a hard inquiry on your credit report?[/INST]
pred:
A debt collector is legally permitted to make a hard inquiry on your credit report when attempting to collect a debt. A hard inquiry occurs when a creditor or debt collector inquires about your credit report, which can have an impact on your credit score. Under the Fair Credit Reporting Act (FCRA), debt collectors are considered "creditors" and are allowed to access your credit report for the purpose of collecting a debt.

When a debt collector makes a hard inquiry on your credit report, it can generally have a negative impact on your credit score, as it indicates that you have had recent credit activity. However, the impact on your score will depend on your individual credit profile and the circumstances surrounding the inquiry.

It's important to note that debt collectors are required to follow certain guidelines when making inquiries on your credit report. They must provide a valid purpose for the inquiry, such as attempting to collect a debt, and must comply with the FCRA's disclosure requirements. Additionally, debt collectors are prohibited from making unnecessary inquiries, such as when they know that the information in your credit report has not changed.

If you're concerned about a hard inquiry on your credit report, you can dispute the inquiry with the creditor or debt collector. You can also request that the creditor
answers: According to the Fair Credit Reporting Act: any consumer reporting agency may furnish a consumer report [...] to a person which it has reason to believe [...] intends to use the information in connection with a credit transaction involving the consumer on whom the information is to be furnished and   involving the extension of credit to, or review or collection of an account of, the consumer See p12 (section 604). The usual interpretation of this that I've heard is that a debt collection agency that owns or has been assigned a debt can make hard pulls on your credit report without your consent. This link seems to support that (and references the same part of the act, among others): According to the Fair Credit Reporting Act, [...], any business can access your credit history without your permission provided the business has a valid "permissible purpose." The FCRA notes that one such permissible purpose is to review your credit information in connection with the collection of a debt. Thus, if you owe money to a debt collector, the debt collector has the legal right to pull and review your credit report. If they haven't been assigned the debt or own it outright, I believe you have a legal right to dispute it. Consult a lawyer if this is actually a situation you face.  Once use for this is if the debt collection agency has trouble locating you; since your credit report normally contains current and past addresses, this is one way to locate you.

answers: An attempt at a simple answer for the normal investor: A normal investor buys stock then later sells that stock. (This is known as "going long", as opposed to "going short").  For the normal investor, a stop order (of either kind) is only used when selling. A stop-loss sell order (or stop sell) is used to sell your stock when it has fallen too much in price, and you don't want to suffer more losses.  If the stock is at $50, you could enter a stop sell at $40, which means if the stock ever falls to $40 or lower, your stock will be sold at whatever price is available (e.g. $35). A stop-loss limit sell order (or stop limit sell) is the same, except you are also saying "but don't sell for less than my limit price".  So you can enter a stop limit sell at $40 with a limit of $39, meaning that if the stock falls to $40, you will then have a limit order in effect to sell the stock at $39 or higher.  Thus your stock will never be sold at $35 or any value below $39, but of course, if the stock falls fast from $40 to $35, your limit sell at $39 will not be done and you will be left still owning the stock (worth at that moment $35, say).

pred:
Related hedges, also known as pair trading, is a risk management strategy used by investors to mitigate potential losses in their portfolios. The basic idea behind related hedges is to identify two highly correlated assets and take a long position in one and a short position in the other. The goal is to profit from the difference in their performance, while also reducing the overall volatility of the portfolio.

For example, if an investor believes that the price of oil and the price of gasoline will move inversely, they could go long on oil and short on gasoline. If the price of oil increases, the price of gasoline is likely to decrease, resulting in a profit for the investor. Conversely, if the price of oil decreases, the price of gasoline is likely to increase, resulting in a profit for the investor.

Related hedges can be used in a variety of ways, including:

1. Long-short strategies: Investors can take a long position in an asset they believe will increase in value and a short position in an asset they believe will decrease in value.
2. Pair trading: Investors can identify two highly correlated assets and take a long position in one and a short position in the other.
3. Event-driven strategies: Investors can use related hedges to
answers: In this type of strategy profit is made when the shares go down as your main position is the short trade of the common stock. The convertible instruments will tend to move in about the same direction as the underlying (what it can be converted to) but less violently as they are traded less (lower volatility and lower volume in the market on both sides), however, they are not being used to make a profit so much as to hedge against the stock going up. Since both the bonds and the preference shares are higher on the list to be repaid if the company declares bankruptcy and the bonds pay out a fixed amount of interest as well, both also help protect against problems that may occur with a long position in the common stock.  Essentially the plan with this strategy is to earn fixed income on the bonds whilst the stock price drops and then to sell both the bonds and buy the stock back on the market to cover the short position. If the prediction that the stock will fall is wrong then you are still earning fixed income on the debt and are able to convert it into stock at the higher price to cover the short sale eliminating, or reducing, the loss made on the short sale. Effectively the profit here is made on the spread between the price of the bond, accounting for the conversion price, and the price of the stock and that fixed income is less volatile (except usually in the junk market) than stock.

Yes, there is a converse to dollar-cost-averaging, which is called "lump-sum investing" or "one-time investing." Lump-sum investing involves investing a large sum of money at one time, rather than spreading it out over a period of time through dollar-cost-averaging.

The main advantage of lump-sum investing is that it allows investors to potentially benefit from market downturns. When the market is low, the value of the investment is lower, so investing a large sum of money at one time can result in a higher potential return on investment (ROI) compared to investing smaller amounts over a period of time. This is because the larger sum invested at a lower price can potentially appreciate more than the smaller amounts invested at a higher price.

However, there are also risks associated with lump-sum investing. One of the main risks is volatility. When investing a large sum of money at one time, the investor may not have the opportunity to spread the risk across a variety of assets, which can result in a higher volatility risk. Additionally, if the market does not recover, the investor may lose a significant portion of their investment.

prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

“Convertible -debt/note/bond/debentures” which of these are the same or different?[/INST]
pred:
Convertible debt, notes, bonds, and debentures are all financial instruments that allow investors to invest in a company with the potential for future equity ownership. While they share some similarities, there are also key differences between these instruments.

Convertible debt is a type of debt security that can be converted into equity shares of the company at a later date. This provides investors with the opportunity to benefit from any potential increase in the company's stock price without having to wait for the debt to mature.

Notes, on the other hand, are similar to bonds but are typically unsecured and have a shorter maturity date. They are often issued by companies to raise capital and can be convertible into equity, similar to convertible debt.

Bonds are a type of debt security that pays interest periodically and returns the principal amount at maturity. They are typically issued by companies to raise capital and are considered a less risky investment compared to stocks.

Debentures are a type of long-term debt security that does not have any security attached to it. They are unsecured and pay a fixed rate of interest periodically before returning the principal amount at maturity.

In summary, convertible debt, notes, and debentures are all types of financial instruments that allow investors to invest in a company with the
answers: They all basically mean the same thing - a type of debt than can be exchanged for (converted into) equity at some point. It's only the mechanics that can be different. A convertible bond is structured just like a regular bond - it (usually) pays periodic interest and has a face value that's due at maturity. The difference is that the bond holder has the option to exchange the debt for equity at some point during the life of the bond.  There can be restrictions on when that conversion is possible, and they typically define a quantity of equity (number of shares) that the bond can be converted into.  If the market price of the shares goes above a price that would make the shares more valuable than the bond, it's in the best interest of the bond holder to convert. A convertible note is typically used to describe a kind of startup financing that does not pay interest or have a face value that's redeemed, but instead is redeemed for equity as part of a later financing round.  Rather than specifying a specific number of shares, the bond holder receives equity at a certain discount to the rest of the market. So they both are debt instruments that can turn into equity investments, just through different mechanisms. A debenture is a fancy word for unsecured debt, and convertible debt could be used to described either structure above, so those terms could mean either type of structure.

answers: There is certainly an obligation in some cases of a company to distribute profit, either as dividend or a stock buy back. Activist investors frequently push for one or the other when a company is doing well - sometimes to the detriment of future growth, in some eyes - and can even file shareholder lawsuits (saying the company is not doing its duty to its shareholders by simply holding onto cash).  Apple famously held out from doing either for years under Steve Jobs, and only in the last few years started doing both - a large dividend and a share buy-back which increases the value of remaining shares (as EPS then goes up with fewer shares out there).  Carl Icahn for example is one of those investors in Apple's case [and in many cases!] who put significant pressure, particularly when they were sitting on hundreds of billions of dollars. Ultimately, a (for-profit) corporation's board is tasked with maximizing its shareholder's wealth; as such, it can buy back shares, pay dividends, sell the company, liquidate the company, or expand the company, at its discretion, so long as it can justify to its shareholders that it is still attempting to maximize the value of their holdings.  Companies in their growth phase often don't return any money and simply reinvest - but the long-term hope is to either return money in the form of dividends on profits, or the sale of the company.

answers: The Creation/Redemption mechanism is how shares of an ETF are created or redeemed as needed and thus is where there can be differences in what the value of the holdings can be versus the trading price. If the ETF is thinly traded, then the difference could be big as more volume would be where the mechanism could kick in as generally there are blocks required so the mechanism usually created or redeemed in lots of 50,000 shares I believe. From the link where AP=Authorized Participant: With ETFs, APs do most of the buying and selling. When APs sense   demand for additional shares of an ETF—which manifests itself when the   ETF share price trades at a premium to its NAV—they go into the market   and create new shares. When the APs sense demand from investors   looking to redeem—which manifests itself when the ETF share price   trades at a discount—they process redemptions. So, suppose the NAV of the ETF is $20/share and the trading price is $30/share. The AP can buy the underlying securities for $20/share in a bulk order that equates to 50,000 shares of the ETF and exchange the underlying shares for new shares in the ETF. Then the AP can turn around and sell those new ETF shares for $30/share and pocket the gain. If you switch the prices around, the AP would then take the ETF shares and exchange them for the underlying securities in the same way and make a profit on the difference. SEC also notes this same process.

UK Gilts are a type of government bond issued by the UK government, with the issuer being the exchequer. When you buy a Gilt, you are essentially lending money to the government for a fixed period of time, in exchange for a fixed rate of return. The interest rate on Gilts is determined by the market forces of supply and demand, and it is usually lower than that of other types of investments, such as stocks or corporate bonds, due to the government's creditworthiness and the fact that the investment is considered to be very low-risk.

The interest on Gilts is typically paid semi-annually, meaning that you will receive a return on your investment every six months. The repayment of the principal amount at maturity is also guaranteed, unless the government defaults on its debt obligations.

There are several types of Gilts available, each with different features and characteristics. For example, Index-Linked Gilts (ILGs) offer a return that is linked to the retail prices index (RPI), while Corporate Bond Gilts (CBGs) offer a return that is linked to the bank of England's base rate. There are also Floating Rate Gilts (FRGs), which offer a return that is linked to a specific interest rate benchmark, such as the
answers: The name of the Gilt states the redemption date, but not the original issue date. A gilt with 8.75% yield and close to its redemption date may have been issued at a time when interest rates were indeed close to 8.75%. For example in the early 1990s, the UK inflation rate was about 8%. One reason for preferring high or low coupon gilts is the trade off between capital gains and income, and the different taxation rules for each. If you buy a gilt and hold it to its maturity date, you know in advance the exact price that it will be redeemed for (i.e. £100). You may prefer to take a high level of income now, knowing you will make a capital loss in future (which might offset some other predictable capital gain for tax purposes) or you may prefer not to take income that you don't need right now, and instead get a guaranteed capital gain in future (for example, when you plan to retire from work). Also, you can use the change in the market value of gilts as a gamble or a hedge against your expectation of interest rate changes in future, with the "government guaranteed" fallback position that if your predictions are wrong, you know exactly what return you will get if you hold the gilts to maturity. The same idea applies to other bond investments - but without the government guarantee, of course.

answers: A UTMA may or may not fit your situation. The main drawbacks to a UTMA account is that it will count against your child for financial aid (it counts as the child's asset). answers: This sometimes happens to me. It depends on how liquid the option is. Normally what I see happening is that the order book mutates itself around my order. I interpret this to mean that the order book is primarily market makers. They see a retail investor (me) come in and, since they don't have any interest in this illiquid option, they back off. Some other retail investor (or whatever) steps in with a market order, and we get matched up. I get a fill because I become the market maker for a brief while. For a while I had a suspicion that this was happening with strikes where IV didn't match IV of other strikes, but I never cared enough to chase it down as it was a minor part of my overall P/L.

answers: The price of the last trade... Is the price of the last trade. It indicates what one particular buyer and seller agreed upon. There is absolutely no requirement that one of them didn't offer too much or demand too little, so this is nearly meaningless as an indication of what anyone else will be willing to offer or demand. An average of trades across a sufficiently large number of transactions might indicate a rough consensus about the value of a stock, but transactions will be clustered around that average and the average itself moves over time. Either you offer to sell or buy at a particular price, wait for that price, and risk the transaction not taking place at all if nobody agrees, or you do a spot transaction and get the best price at that nanosecond (which may not be the best in the next nanosecond). Or you tell the broker what the limits are that you consider acceptable, trading these risks off against each other. Pick the one which comes closest to your intent and ignore the fact that others may be getting a slightly different price. That's just the way the market works. Debt can be broadly classified into two categories: good debt and bad debt. This type of debt can provide a financial return and help increase wealth in the long run.

On the other hand, bad debt, also known as non-productive debt, is debt that is taken on to purchase assets that do not appreciate in value over time, such as consumer goods or services. This type of debt does not provide a financial return and can actually decrease wealth if not managed properly.

1. Purpose: Good debt is taken on to purchase assets that will appreciate in value over time, while bad debt is taken on to purchase assets that do not appreciate in value.
2. Return on investment: Good debt provides a financial return, such as rental income or dividends, while bad debt does not provide a financial return.
3. Interest rate: Good debt typically has a lower interest rate than bad debt, as the lender is taking on more risk.
4. Payment structure: Good debt often has a longer repayment term than bad debt, which allows for lower month

Are wash sale rules different for stocks and ETFs / Mutual Funds?[/INST]
pred:
Yes, the wash sale rules are different for stocks, ETFs/mutual funds, and other securities. In general, the wash sale rule is intended to prevent investors from claiming a loss on a security that they have sold at a loss and then repurchasing the same or substantially identical security within 30 days before or after the sale. However, the rule applies differently to different types of securities.

For stocks, the wash sale rule is strict and applies regardless of the type of account in which the stock is held. If an investor sells a stock at a loss and then buys the same stock or a substantially identical stock within 30 days before or after the sale, the loss will be disallowed and treated as a deferral of the loss. The investor will have to wait until the end of the tax year to claim the loss.

For ETFs/mutual funds, the wash sale rule is more relaxed. If an investor sells a mutual fund or ETF at a loss and then buys a substantially identical mutual fund or ETF within 30 days before or after the sale, the loss will be disallowed only to the extent of the amount of the gain realized on the sale of the mutual fund or ETF. In other words, the investor can offset the loss on the sale of the
answers: The IRS rules are actually the same.  26 U.S. Code § 1091 - Loss from wash sales of stock or securities In   the case of any loss claimed to have been sustained from any sale or   other disposition of shares of stock or securities where it appears   that, within a period beginning 30 days before the date of such sale   or disposition and ending 30 days after such date, the taxpayer has   acquired (by purchase or by an exchange on which the entire amount of   gain or loss was recognized by law), or has entered into a contract or   option so to acquire, substantially identical stock or securities,   then no deduction shall be allowed... What you should take away from the quote above is "substantially identical stock or securities." With stocks, one company may happen to have a high correlation, Exxon and Mobil come to mind, before their merger of course. With funds or ETFs, the story is different. The IRS has yet to issue rules regarding what level of overlap or correlation makes two funds or ETFs "substantially identical." prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

Are capitalization rate and net profit margin the same thing?[/INST]
pred:
No, capitalization rate and net profit margin are not the same thing, although they are related concepts in real estate investment analysis.

Capitalization rate, also known as cap rate, is the ratio of net operating income (NOI) to property value. It measures the return on investment based on the income generated by a property. Cap rate is calculated by dividing the NOI by the property's value. For example, if a property generates $100,000 in NOI and has a value of $1 million, the cap rate would be 10% ($100,000 / $1 million).

Net profit margin, on the other hand, is the ratio of net income to revenue. It measures the profitability of a business or investment based on the income earned after deducting all expenses. Net profit margin is calculated by dividing net income by revenue. For example, if a business has net income of $100,000 and revenue of $500,000, the net profit margin would be 20% ($100,000 / $500,000).

While both cap rate and net profit margin are used to measure profitability, they are calculated differently and have different applications. Cap rate is more commonly used in real estate investment analysis to estimate the potential return
answers: Both of these terms do refer to your profit; they're just different ways of evaluating it. First, your definition of capitalization rate is flipped.  As explained here, it should be: On the other hand, as explained here: So cap rate is like a reverse unit cost approach to comparing two investments.  If house A costs $1M and you'll make $50K (profit) from it yearly, and house B costs $1.33M and you'll make $65K (profit) from it yearly, then you can compute cap rates to see that A is a more efficient investment from the point of view of income vs. amount-of-money-you-have-stuck-in-this-investment-and-unavailable-for-use-elsewhere. Profit margin, on the other hand, cares more about your ongoing expenses than about your total investment.  If it costs less to maintain property B than it does to maintain property A, then you could have something like: So B is a more efficient investment from the point of view of the fraction of your revenue you actually get to keep each year. Certainly you could think of the property's value as an opportunity cost and factor that into the net profit margin equation to get a more robust estimate of exactly how efficient your investment is.  You can keep piling more factors into the equation until you've accounted for every possible facet of your investment.  This is what accountants and economists spend their days doing. :-)

prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

How much is one “lot” of EUR/USD?[/INST]
pred:
A "lot" in the context of currency trading is a standardized amount of a particular currency pairs that is used to standardize trade sizes and facilitate trading on financial markets. The size of a lot can vary depending on the currency pair and the brokerage firm, but here are some common lot sizes used in the forex market:

* Micro lots: These are the smallest lots, typically equal to 10,000 units of the base currency in a currency pair. For example, in EUR/USD, a micro lot would be 10,000 euros.
* Mini lots: These are larger than micro lots and typically equal to 100,000 units of the base currency in a currency pair. For example, in EUR/USD, a mini lot would be 100,000 euros.
* Standard lots: These are the most common lots and typically equal to 1,000,000 units of the base currency in a currency pair. For example, in EUR/USD, a standard lot would be 1 million euros.

So, to answer your question, one "lot" of EUR/USD is equivalent to 10,000 euros in a micro lot, 100,000 euros in a mini lot, or 1
answers: A lot (sometimes called a round lot) always refers to the quantity of physical good that you're getting, like a carton of eggs or a barrel of oil.  The tricky thing in the case of forex is that the physical good also happens to be a currency. A spot currency product trades in the denomination on the right-hand side (RHS) of the product name.  So if you're buying EUR/USD you are paying USD currency to get EUR "units", and if you're selling EUR/USD you are receiving USD by giving away EUR "units".  The EUR is the "physical good" in this case. The way I remember it is to think of all products (not just currencies) as trading pairs.  So AAPL in my mind is AAPL/USD.  When I buy AAPL/USD I am paying USD to get AAPL units.  When I sell AAPL/USD I am receiving USD by giving away AAPL units. The thing on the left is the physical good (even if it happens to be money) that you are exchanging, and the thing on the right is the money that you are exchanging. So, when I buy a lot of AAPL, I am buying 100 shares at their current price in dollars. Similarly, when I buy a lot of EUR/USD, I am buying 100K Euros at their current price in dollars.

Are RSUs ever taxed as long term capital gains?[/INST]
pred:
RSUs (Restricted Stock Units) are a type of employee compensation that is taxed as ordinary income when they are granted or vest. However, when RSUs are sold, they may be eligible for long-term capital gains treatment, depending on the holding period.

In general, if an employee holds RSUs for more than one year after they are granted or vest, any gain on the sale of the RSUs will be eligible for long-term capital gains treatment. Long-term capital gains are taxed at a lower rate than ordinary income, with the maximum federal long-term capital gains tax rate currently set at 20% for most taxpayers.

It's important to note that the holding period for RSUs begins on the date of grant or vesting, so it's important to keep accurate records of the dates of grant and vesting to determine if the RSUs have been held for the required amount of time. Additionally, state tax laws may vary, so it's important to consult with a tax professional to determine the tax implications of RSUs in your specific situation.

It's also worth noting that there may be additional tax implications to consider when selling RSUs, such as the alternative minimum tax (AMT) and the 3.8% net investment income tax (NIIT). A tax

The world, in aggregate, generates a non-zero return through the functioning of financial markets. Financial markets enable the allocation of capital across different investment opportunities, allowing individuals, businesses, and governments to Borrow and Lend to each other. This creates a return on investment (ROI) through the difference between the cost of capital (interest rates) and the expected return on investment (equity).

When an investor lends money (capital) to a borrower, they expect to earn a return in the form of interest payments. The interest rate is determined by the prevailing market conditions and the perceived risk of the borrower. For example, a government issuing bonds to raise capital will typically offer a lower interest rate than a private company with a higher perceived risk of default.

The borrower, on the other hand, needs to pay interest on the borrowed capital to attract funding. This interest payment is the return on investment for the lender, who is providing the capital.

In a free market economy, the supply and demand for capital are balanced through market forces. When demand for capital exceeds supply, interest rates tend to increase, making borrowing more expensive. Conversely, when supply exceeds demand, interest rates tend to decrease, making borrowing cheaper.

On the one hand, they can incentivize businesses to invest in new technologies or initiatives that could lead to economic growth and job creation. If you have a moderate (>$40,000) income, then taxes should be one the largest, if not the largest chunk of your paycheck out the door.  I personally track my cash flow on a day-by-day basis. That is to say, I break out the actual cash payments (paychecks) that I receive and break them apart into the 14 day increments (paycheck/14). I then take my expenses and do the same. If you organize your expenses into categories, you will receive some meaningful numbers about your daily liquidity (i.e: cash flow before taxes, after taxes, cash flow after house expenses, ect) This serves two purposes. One, you will understand how much you can actually spend on a day-to-day basis. Second, once you realize your flexibility on a day-to-day basis, it is easy to plan and forecast your expenses.

answers: A lien is a mechanism to impede legal title transfer of a vehicle, real property, or sometimes, expensive business equipment.  That's why title companies exist - to make sure there are no liens against something before a buyer hands money to a seller. The lien can be attached to a loan, unpaid labor related to the item (a mechanic's lien) or unpaid taxes, and there are other scenarios where this could occur. The gist of all this is that the seller of the vehicle mentioned does not have clear title if there is a lien.  This introduces a risk for the buyer.  The buyer can pay the seller the money to cover the lien (in the case of a bank loan) but that doesn't mean the seller will actually pay off the loan (so the title is never clear!).  This article recommends visiting the bank with the seller, and getting title on-the-spot.  However, this isn't always an option, as a local bank branch isn't probably going to have the title document available, though the seller might be able to make some arrangement for a local branch to have the title available before a visit to pay off the loan. The low-risk approach is for the seller to have clear title before any money changes hands.

prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

What is the meaning of “short selling” or “going short” a stock?[/INST]
pred:
Short selling, also known as "going short" a stock, is a financial strategy in which an investor sells a security that they do not own with the intention of buying it back at a lower price to realize a profit. This is in contrast to buying a security, also known as "going long," where an investor buys a security with the expectation of selling it at a higher price in the future to realize a profit.

 Short selling involves borrowing shares of a stock from a broker or other investor and selling them at the current market price. The investor then waits for the stock price to decrease, at which point they buy back the borrowed shares at the lower price and return them to the lender. The difference between the original selling price and the lower buying price represents the profit from the short sale.

Short selling can be a profitable strategy when an investor expects the price of a stock to decline. It can also be used to hedge against potential losses in a long position, such as when an investor owns a stock that they believe may decrease in value. However, short selling also involves risks, including the potential for unlimited losses if the stock price rises instead of declines.

Short selling is a common practice in financial markets and is used by both individual investors and institutional investors, such as hedge funds
answers: The reason for selling a stock "short", is for when you believe the stock value will decrease in the near future. Here is an example: Today Exxon-Mobile stock is selling for $100 / share. You are expecting the price to decrease, so you want to short the stock, which means your broker (i.e. eTrade, etc) allows you to borrow shares without paying money, and those shares are transferred into your account, and then you sell them and receive money for the sale. But you didn't actually own those shares, you only borrowed them, so you need to return the shares to your broker sometime in the future.  Let's say you borrow 10 shares @ $100, and you sell them at the market price of $100, you receive $1,000 in your account. But you owe your broker 10 shares, which you need to return sometime in the future. A few days later, the share price has decreased to $80. Now you can buy 10 shares from the market at a total cost of $800. You get 10 shares, and return those shares to your broker. Since you originally took in $1,000, and you just paid out $800, you keep a resulting profit of $200

The most common ROI vs risk graph is the "efficient frontier," which is a graph that shows the potential return and risk of an investment strategy for different levels of risk tolerance. The efficient frontier is a curve that represents the highest possible return for a given level of risk, or the lowest possible risk for a given level of return.

For example, consider a graph that shows the efficient frontier for a portfolio of stocks and bonds. The graph would have a series of yield curves, each representing a different level of risk. The curve with the highest potential return would be the most aggressive investment, while the curve with the lowest potential return would be the least aggressive investment.

Here are some key takeaways from a ROI vs risk graph:

1. The curve that represents the highest potential return for a given level of risk is the "efficient frontier."
2. The efficient frontier is a tradeoff between return and risk.
3. A portfolio with a higher potential return will typically have a higher level of risk.

Why would a tender offer be less than the market price?[/INST]
pred:
A tender offer is a public announcement by an investor or company to purchase a certain number of shares of a publicly traded company at a specified price. Sometimes, a tender offer may be less than the current market price of the shares, and there are several reasons why this could happen.

One reason is that the investor or company making the tender offer may not be willing to pay the current market price for the shares. This could be due to a variety of factors, such as a lack of confidence in the company's prospects, concerns about the company's financial health, or simply a belief that the shares are overvalued. By making a tender offer at a lower price than the market price, the investor or company may be able to acquire the shares at a more attractive price than what they would pay in the open market.

Another reason for a tender offer to be less than the market price is that the investor or company may be trying to limit the amount of shares they will purchase. By making a lower offer, they can attract shareholders who are willing to sell at that price, while still avoiding the higher costs associated with purchasing a larger number of shares. This can help the investor or company to achieve their desired level of ownership in the company without overpaying for the shares.

Additionally, a tender offer may be less than the market price if the investor or company is
answers: As an addition to Chris Rea's excellent answer, these tender offers are sometimes made specifically to cast doubt on the current market price. For instance, a large public company that contracts with a smaller supplier or service company, also public, might make a tender offer below market price. The market will look at this price and the business relationship, and wonder what the larger company knows about the smaller one that they don't. Now, what happens when investors lose confidence in a stock? They sell it, supply goes up, demand goes down, and the price drops. The company making the tender offer can then get its shares either way; directly via the offer, or on the open market. This is, however, usually not successful beyond the very short term, and typically only works because the company making a tender offer is the 800-pound gorilla, which can dictate its own terms with practically anyone else it meets. Such offers are also very closely watched by the SEC; if there's any hint that the larger company is acting in a predatory manner, or that its management is using the power and information of the company to profit themselves, the strategy will backfire as the larger company finds itself the target of SEC and DoJ legal proceedings.

In this case, the tradesman can claim back the VAT they paid on the materials as input tax, providing they can demonstrate that they have incurred the VAT on legitimate expenses.

As more investors move their money into index funds, the demand for the stocks in the index increases, which can drive up their prices.

There are several factors that contribute to the potential for a pricing bubble in index-fund stocks:

1. Network effects: As more investors move into index funds, the demand for the stocks in the index increases, creating a positive feedback loop. This can lead to a self-reinforcing cycle of buying and driving up prices.
2. Passive investing: Index funds are designed to be passive investment vehicles, which means they don't actively manage their portfolios. This can lead to a herd mentality, where investors follow the crowd and buy the same stocks, further driving up prices.
3. Low interest rates: Low interest rates can make stocks more attractive to investors, particularly those investing for the long term. This increased demand can drive up prices, even if the underlying fundamentals of the companies are not as strong.
4. Diversification: Index funds

prompt:

How to distinguish gift from payment for the service?[/INST]
pred:
Hello! I'm here to help you with your question. It's important to distinguish between gifts and payments for services to ensure compliance with tax laws and regulations. Here are some key factors to consider:

1. Intent: Check the intent behind the payment. If the payment is made with the intention of showing appreciation or gratitude for a service provided, it may be considered a gift. On the other hand, if the payment is made in exchange for a service, it may be considered a payment for services.
2. Value: Look at the value of the payment. If the payment is nominal or minor compared to the value of the service provided, it may be considered a gift. However, if the payment is significant compared to the value of the service provided, it may be considered a payment for services.
3. Relationship: Consider the nature of the relationship between the parties involved. If the parties have a personal or close relationship, a payment made may be considered a gift. However, if the parties are unrelated or have a professional relationship, a payment made may be considered a payment for services.
4. Documentation: Check if there is any documentation to support the payment. If the payment is made with a clear understanding of its purpose and value, it may be considered a payment for services. On the other hand, if there is no documentation or the documentation is unclear, it may be considered a gift.
answers: Most people will never need to pay federal gift taxes. The federal gift taxes start after giving away 5.34 million over the course of your life. This number is adjusted annually for inflation. There are only two states that I know of which impose state gift taxes (Connecticut and Minnesota); in Connecticut, you need to start paying taxes if the lifetime value of your gifts exceed two million. In Minnesota, it starts at 1 million.  The federal tax is paid for by the person making the gift, unless other arrangements are made. There is an annual exclusion amount of approximately $14,000. You can give up to this amount to any number of recipients and it is not considered taxable. Therefore, when you give $100 to someone, it is not a taxable event.  If you do make a gift to an individual in excess of 14k, you'll need to file a gift tax return (IRS Form 709). When you file form 709, you won't need to pay taxes until the 5.34 million is exceeded. Instead, you can claim an exemption. Since most people don't exceed that amount, its rare to ever pay taxes even when exceeding the annual exclusion amount. The annual exclusion amount is adjusted each year for inflation.

pred:
The U.S. government cannot retroactively tax gains made earlier in the fiscal year. Under U.S. tax law, the Internal Revenue Code (IRC) sets forth the rules for taxing income, including capital gains, earned during the tax year. The tax year runs from January 1 to December 31 of each year.

Once the tax year has ended, the IRS cannot go back and tax gains that were earned during that year. This is known as the "statute of limitations," which sets a time limit on how long the IRS can audit and assess taxes on tax returns. For individual taxpayers, the statute of limitations is typically three years from the date the return was filed or the date the tax was paid, whichever is later.

There are some exceptions to this general rule, however. For example, if the IRS discovers a "substantial understatement of income" on a tax return, it may have up to six years to audit and assess additional taxes. Additionally, if a taxpayer fails to file a tax return or files a fraudulent return, the IRS may have longer time frames to audit and assess taxes.

In summary, the U.S. government cannot retroactively tax gains made earlier in the fiscal year because of the statute of limitations and other tax laws
answers: You're certainly referring to "Ex Post Facto" laws, and while the US is constitutionally prohibited from passing criminal laws that are retroactive, the US Supreme Court has upheld many tax laws that apply tax code changes retroactively. You might ask a similar question on Law.SE for a more thorough treatment of the legalities of congress passing those laws, but I will stick to the personal finance portion of the question. What this means is that you can't expect that the current tax laws will be in force in the future, and your investment/retirement plans should be as flexible as possible. You may wish to have some money in both Roth and traditional 401(k) accounts. You might not want to have millions of dollars in Roth accounts, because if congress does act to limit the tax benefits of those accounts, it will probably be targeting the larger balances. If you are valuing tax deductions, you should put slightly more weight on deductions that you can take today than deductions that would apply in the future. If you do find yourself in trouble because of a retroactive change, be sure to consult a tax lawyer that specializes in dealing with the IRS to possibly negotiate a settlement for a lower amount than the full tax bill that results from the changes.

If the U.S. defaults on its debt, what will happen to my bank money? [/INST]
pred:
If the United States defaults on its debt, it could have significant implications for the global financial system and impact various financial instruments, including bank money. In the event of a default, the U.S. government would likely face a credit crisis, which could lead to a general loss of confidence in the dollar as a global reserve currency. This could result in a decline in the value of the dollar, higher inflation, and potentially a recession.

In terms of bank money, the impact would depend on the specific type of account. Here are some possible scenarios:

1. Savings accounts: Deposits in savings accounts are insured by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC) up to $250,000 per account. While a default by the U.S. government would likely cause significant instability in the financial system, the deposit insurance coverage would provide a measure of protection for savings account holders. However, there is still a risk of capital losses if the bank fails or if the value of the dollar declines.
2. Checking accounts: Checking accounts are also insured by the FDIC, but the coverage is limited to $250,000 per account. As with savings accounts, the deposit insurance would provide some protection for checking account holders, but there is still a risk of capital losses.
answers: There are many different things that can happen, all or some. Taking Russia and Argentina as precedence - you may not be able to withdraw funds from your bank for some period of time. Not because your accounts will be drained, but because the cash supply will be restricted. Similar thing has also happened recently in Cyprus. However, the fact that the governments of Russia and Argentina limited the use of cash for a period of time doesn't mean that the US government will have to do the same, it my choose some other means of restraint. What's for sure is that nothing good will happen. Nothing will probably happen to your balance in the bank (Although Cyprus has shown that that is not a given either). But I'm not so sure about FDIC maintaining it's insurance if the bank fails (meaning if the bank defaults as a result of the chain effect - you may lose your money). If the government is defaulting, it might not have enough cash to take over the bank deposits. After the default the currency value will probably drop sharply (devaluation) which will lead to inflation. Meaning your same balance will be worth much less than it is now. So there's something to worry about for everyone.

prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

Is the Swiss stock market inversely correlated with the Swiss Franc like Japan today?[/INST]
pred:
The Swiss stock market and Swiss Franc are closely intertwined, as the Francisco is the country's official currency. However, their relationship is not always inversely correlated. In recent years, there has been a negative correlation between the Swiss stock market and the Swiss Franc, meaning that when the Franc strengthens, the stock market tends to weaken. This is because a strong Franc makes Swiss exports less competitive, leading to a decline in the stock market.

Japan's stock market, on the other hand, is not necessarily inversely correlated with the Japanese Yen. While there is some evidence of a negative correlation between the two, particularly in the short term, the relationship is not as smooth or consistent as it is between the Swiss Franc and Swiss stock market. This is because Japan's stock market is influenced by a range of factors, including economic growth, interest rates, and global economic trends, while the Yen's value is primarily driven by foreign exchange market fundamentals.

In conclusion, while there is some evidence of an inverse correlation between the Swiss stock market and the Swiss Franc, the relationship is not always consistent or predictable. Similarly, the relationship between Japan's stock market and the Yen is complex and influenced by a range of factors, making it difficult to make sweeping generalizations about their relationship.

The main export market for Switzerland is the UE. Some companies are doing most or all of their business on the Swiss market. Others are much more exposed to the the health of the global economy. When the Swiss franc appreciates, some companies suffer a lot from that and other less. It depends on their product portfolio, competitors, and other factors. The last decades have shown that how the Swiss Franc valuation is less and less correlated with the performance of the Swiss economy. The Swiss franc is used as a safe haven when the global economy goes bad or is uncertain. In those times, the Swiss franc can be overevaluated, at least as compared to the purchasing power. When the global economy is improving, the over-appreciation of the Swiss franc tends to disapear ; this is happening now (in Mid-2017). As a summary, the Swiss franc itself is not truly correlated with the competitiveness of the Swiss economy, but more about how people in the world are anxious. In this regard, it behaves a little bit like gold.

What is the opposite of Economic Bubble? [/INST]
pred:
The opposite of an economic bubble is a sustainable and healthy economic growth, characterized by a stable and balanced market. An economic bubble occurs when there is a rapid increase in prices of assets, such as stocks, housing, or commodities, without a corresponding increase in underlying fundamentals, leading to a sudden and sharp decline in prices.

On the other hand, a sustainable economic growth is driven by fundamentals such as strong earnings, low inflation, and solid consumer demand, which leads to a gradual and steady increase in asset prices. This type of growth is considered sustainable because it is not fueled by speculation or artificial stimuli, but rather by the underlying strength of the economy.

Some key differences between an economic bubble and sustainable economic growth include:

* Speed: An economic bubble tends to occur rapidly, with prices rising quickly and then collapsing even faster. Sustainable economic growth, on the other hand, occurs gradually, with prices rising steadily over time.
* Underlying fundamentals: An economic bubble is not supported by any underlying fundamentals, while sustainable economic growth is driven by strong economic fundamentals such as earnings, inflation, and consumer demand.
* Market sentiment: An economic bubble is often fueled by market sentiment, with investors becoming overly optimistic and spec
answers: The opposite of an economic bubble is a bubble burst :p! Jokes aside though, an economic bubble occurs when the economy is in bull market mode and asset prices are growing very fast. It's usually measured by ratio's like price to earnings and the levels of various market indices. So, the opposite would be when valuations are falling very fast or are very low, and price to earnings ratios are low.  This condition is usually a recession. A recession is a market slowdown, generally after a bubble bursts, and severe recessions can become depressions if they last long enough (Great Depression, 1930s).  A bubble is not necessarily negative - stock prices usually rise a lot so paper wealth is greatly magnified. If you can get out in time, you're golden. Similarly, a recession isn't bad for everyone. Some investors keep large amounts of cash waiting for recessions so they can "buy low, sell high". For most people, however, recessions are negative because unemployment increases and some people get fired, and the economy slows down. Asset prices have fallen so their investments are worth less than they used to be (on paper), and people mainly have to bide it out until the market starts growing again.

As a helpful assistant, I can provide you with information on whether a business can refuse to take credit cards. In general, businesses in the United States are not legally required to accept credit cards, but there are certain restrictions and considerations they should be aware of.

The Electronic Fund Transfer Act (EFTA), which is part of the Truth in Lending Act, prohibits merchants from charging customers extra fees for using credit cards. However, merchants are allowed to pass along the interchange fees that banks charge them for processing credit card transactions. These fees can range from 1% to 3% of the transaction amount, depending on the type of card and the merchant category.

There are some exceptions to the EFTA's prohibition on extra fees. For example, merchants can charge customers a higher price if they choose to pay with a credit card instead of a debit card or cash. This practice is known as "swipe fees" or "interchange fees." However, merchants must clearly disclose their swipe fee policy and obtain the customer's consent before imposing the fee.

In addition to federal laws, there may be state-specific laws that regulate credit card transactions and merchants' ability to refuse credit card payments. For example, some states have laws that prohibit merchants from charging higher prices for credit

This means that the co-signer's credit history and credit score play a significant role in determining the interest rate and terms of the loan.

Here are a few ways that having a co-signer on your car loan can affect your credit:

1. Joint liability: By adding a co-signer to the loan, you are both equally responsible for repaying the loan. This means that your co-signer's credit behavior can impact your credit score, even if you make all the payments on time.
2. Credit mix: Having a co-signer on your car loan can diversify your credit mix, which can help your credit score. However, if your co-signer has a low credit score or a history of missed payments, this could negatively impact your credit score.
3. Credit utilization: The amount of debt that you and your co-signer have borrowed can impact your credit
answers: It sounds like your father got a loan and you are making the payments.  If your name and SSN are not on the loan then you are not getting credit for making the payments your father is. Since your father is named as the primary borrower you will probably need to talk with him about it first. If your fathers name is the primary name on the title then you would have to retitle the car to refinance in your name.

Similarly, any shares sold before June 20 will be eligible to receive the dividend, regardless of when they were purchased.

However, if the company is based abroad, it may not be worth the expense for them to have an additional securities listing on the local (US) exchange. What is a negotiable security and how are they related to derivatives?[/INST]
pred:
A negotiable security is a financial instrument that can be transfered or negotiated, meaning it can be sold or assigned to another party. The most common type of negotiable security is a stock, but it can also include bonds, certificates of deposit (CDs), and other financial instruments.

Negotiable securities are related to derivatives in that derivatives are contracts that derive their value from an underlying asset or group of assets. Derivatives can be based on a variety of underlying assets, including stocks, bonds, commodities, currencies, and interest rates. Some common derivatives include options, futures, and swaps.

When a negotiable security is used as the underlying asset for a derivative, it is called a "дире fungible security." For example, a company may issue a bond that can be traded on a stock exchange, and then use that bond as the underlying asset for a futures contract. In this case, the futures contract would derive its value from the price of the bond.

Investors may use negotiable securities as collateral for derivatives in order to gain exposure to a particular asset class without actually owning the asset. For example, an investor may own shares of a company but want to gain exposure to the commodity market. They could use the shares as collateral for a commodity futures contract, which
answers: negotiability is a legal concept that permits free transfer of a security without the requirement of prior consent of the issuer.  that means the issuer must pay the current holder of the security, irrespective of who he is.  negotiability also protects a good faith buyer of the instrument from adverse ownership claims of purported prior holders of the instrument.  it is not related to "negotiating" the price or whatnot.  A negotiable security means the current owner does not have to be concerned about acquiring the asset via a bad chain of title b/c he can always assert that he is a "holder in due course" defense against such claims, and have absolute security in his ownership right over the asset.  securities and derivatives are different.  securities are transferrable instruments representing a direct claim on the issuer for the value of the security, whether debt or equity ownership.  derivatives are bilateral contracts, which can only be entered into with the consent of both parties, and can only be transferred by such consent.  derivatives represent a claim against the parties of to the derivative that depends on some economic reference which is outside of the financial condition of the two parties to the contract, such as interest rates, FX rates, commodity prices, etc.
